message.content: Yes, the authors used crowdsourcing through Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT). They describe potential risks and benefits for the participants and mention the consent form that participants need to read and agree to before participating in the experiment. However, links to Institutional Review Board (IRB) approvals are not explicitly mentioned in the provided sections.

Yes, the authors conducted research with human subjects using Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT) and mentioned potential participant risks, benefits, and confidentiality. The participants were asked to read and agree to a consent form specifying the objective and procedure of the experiment, the expected time for completion, the associated reward, and information about risks, benefits, and confidentiality when taking part in the study. The authors stated that there are no anticipated risks and no direct benefits for the participants taking part in this study. However, they did not provide explicit links to Institutional Review Board (IRB) approvals.

Yes, the authors describe potential participant risks and mention issues related to the research with human subjects. They used Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT) for their experiments and prioritized users with high qualifications. Participants were asked to read and agree to a consent form which specifies the objective, procedure, time expected to completion, associated rewards, and risks, benefits, and confidentiality of taking part in the study. They mention there are no anticipated risks and no direct benefits for the participants. However, they did not provide explicit links to Institutional Review Board (IRB) approvals.
